records.Name: Families Moving Forward - Evening
records.Description_Short__c: The NEST (Neighbors Experiencing Success Together) provides temporary housing for families with children combined with programs to help them build skills to return to a stable lifestyle and permanent housing as quickly as possible.

records.Name: UMD: Hope-Believe Recovery Program
records.Description_Short__c: Intensive live-in drug and alcohol rehabilitation program for homeless men and women. Modeled after a 12-Step Alcoholics Anonymous program, participants also receive case management support and connections to housing and employment services. There is no cost for the program, but there is limited space, and participants must apply for the program and actively participate in their recovery to remain.
records.F_Description_Short__c: provides substance abuse support to male adults.
records.Detailed_Description__c: The goals are to provide recovery in a structured and supportive environment and ultimately empower participants to manage their illness, maintain sobriety, improve health and wellness, and move to self-sufficiency. The program incorporates education about addiction illness, role modeling, peer review and accountability and a system of rewards to encourage and maintain sobriety.

records.Name: Alcohol/Drug Council of North Carolina
records.Description_Short__c: Provides substance abuse education and prevention in the form of support groups for sufferers and their families as well as recovery housing. Has a special program for pregnant women and parents.
records.Imported_Phone__c:
Text M-F 12pm- 6pm: 919-908-3196
Call for treatment referral: 1-800-688-4232
Sunrise Recovery Resource Center: (919) 973-2799
records.F_Description_Short__c: ACDCNC/Alchohol Drug Council of North Carolina provides substance abuse education and prevention. Serves any person in need.
records.Detailed_Description__c: ADCNC is not associated with any treatment program - our call responders are available to listen, navigate your situation and help you locate services.  Your call is completely confidential.
records.Primary_Street__c: Sunrise Recovery Resource Center: 1201 N Roxboro Street

records.Name: Genesis DWI Services
records.Description_Short__c: Services include substance abuse assessments and treatment, DWI assessments, Driving While License Revoked assessments, Alcohol Drug Education Traffic School (ADETS), DMV evaluation, therapy for individual/group/family, anger management assessment and groups, and specialized treatment for special needs populations such as veterans, lesbians, gay, bisexual and transgender community and individuals with dual diagnoses.
records.F_Description_Short__c: Licensed by the State of NC to help individuals charged with a drug or alcohol offense (individual /group therapy and court mandated DWI Substance Abuse Assessments). Drug Education and Anger Management Classes. Counseling services (including alchohol and
records.Detailed_Description__c:
• Substance Abuse Assessments

  • DWI Assessments

  • Driving While License Revoked Assessments

  • Alcohol Drug Education Traffic School (ADETS)

  • DMV Evaluation

  • Substance Abuse Education Program: Road To Recovery

  • Short and Long Term Substance Abuse Treatment

  • Short or Long Term Therapy for Individual/Group/Family

  • Anger Management Assessment and Groups

  • Treatment for special needs populations such as veterans, lesbians, gay, bisexual and transgender community and individuals with dual diagnoses

Substance Abuse Education Program:

This evidence based program provides drug information and education about the effects of drugs and for those already in the grip of addiction. This is a ten hour course offered on consecutive Monday nights.
records.Eligibility_Criteria__c:
Items Necessary for an Assessment:

Traffic Citation- can be obtained from the Clerk of Court

Blood Alcohol Concentration level - can be found on your citation or can be obtained from the City/County Bureau of Identification (CCBI) located at: 330 South Salisbury Street, Raleigh, NC 27601. (919) 856-6300

Copy of Court Judgement- can be obtained from the Clerk of Court

NC DMV Driver Vehicle Record- can be obtained from DMV. A Certified True Copy of your driving history is needed; the generated report must not be older than 30 days.

records.Name: Durham Rescue Mission - Thrift Store
records.Description_Short__c: Clothes, shoes, books, CDs, DVDs, VHS, electronics, kitchenware, furniture, linens, rugs - all at extremely discounted prices. Has Raleigh, Chapel Hill and Durham locations (Durham listed).
records.F_Description_Short__c: Clothes, shoes, books, CDs, DVDs, VHS, electronics, kitchenware, furniture, linens, rugs - all at extremely discounted prices. Has Raleigh, Chapel Hill and Durham locations (Durham listed).
records.Detailed_Description__c:
Whether you are interested in donating your gently-used items, searching for a new (to you!) piece of furniture, or volunteering with our thrift store staff in your spare time, we welcome you to the Durham Rescue Mission Thrift Store near the Chapel Hill area.

The Durham Rescue Mission is happy to accept a variety of donations at our Chapel Hill Blvd. thrift store during normal business hours. In-kind donations are completely tax deductible, and all proceeds go to benefit our homeless and addiction ministry in the Triangle. To schedule a pick-up time for larger items, please call 919-401-1935

records.Name: Caring and Sharing Center
records.Description_Short__c: Provides gently used clothing and household goods in good condition for the needy in our community and surrounding counties.
records.F_Description_Short__c: Provides gently used clothing and household goods in good condition for the needy in our community and surrounding counties.
records.Eligibility_Criteria__c:
​Clothing closet is open to anyone but limited to 2 times per month.
Everyone is required to sign in upon arrival.

records.Name: Habitat for Humanity
records.Description_Short__c: Habitat homeowners purchase their home directly from Habitat through a zero-interest, 20-year loan. Includes 325 hours of sweat equity.
records.Imported_Address__c: 1829 E Franklin St Chapel Hill NC 27514
records.F_Description_Short__c: Habitat homeowners purchase their home directly from Habitat through a zero-interest, 20-year loan. Includes 325 hours of sweat equity.
records.Detailed_Description__c:
Program Details:

  • A homeownership program that provides homes through a zero-interest, 20-year loan of $75,000 to $120,000 and 325 hours of sweat equity.

About the housing:

  • The typical home that habitat builds is 1100 sq. ft. with three bedrooms and one or one and a half baths.

  • Homes are built to Energy Star / Systems Visions standards and current builds are green certified.

  • They also have a universal design to assist individuals with physical disabilities.

About the application:

  • Potential applicants must attend a Habitat Homeownership Orientation to receive the application. To learn about the next orientation, call 919-932-7077.

Next steps:

  • If you think you are eligible, call 919-932-7077 to determine when the next homeownership orientation is.

  • Applications are available online and must be completed submitted to them in person. Please read carefully and fill the application out thoroughly as incomplete applications will not be considered.
records.Eligibility_Criteria__c:
• Persons 18+

  • Currently live in a dilapidated home OR rental payments are 33% or more of income OR current housing is overcrowded

  • Live or work in Orange County for at least 1 year.

  • Demonstrate stable income for the past two years.

  • Earn 60% or less than the Area Median Income (AMI).

  • Have no unpaid judgments nor medical collections more than $1000.

  • Can afford a monthly mortgage payment of up to $650

  • Can afford a one-time closing cost of $1700.

  • Be willing to perform 325 hours of sweat equity to help build Habitat homes.

records.Name: Town of Chapel Hill Public Housing
records.Description_Short__c: Provides decent, safe and affordable rental housing to Chapel Hill’s public housing families.
records.Imported_Address__c: 317 Caldwell Street Extension Chapel Hill, NC 27516
records.CEF_TEam_View__c: Town of Chapel Hill Public Housing
records.F_Description_Short__c: Provides decent, safe and affordable rental housing to Chapel Hill’s public housing families.
records.Detailed_Description__c:
Committed to providing programs and services to help public housing families improve basic life skills and achieve economic independence. The Department manages 336 public housing apartments in 13 neighborhoods throughout Chapel Hill and Carrboro. Community service requirement for all residents over 18.

About the Application:

  • Complete an application and submit in person at town hall
  • Must bring picture ID, Social Security card, birth certificates for children
  • Background check required
  • Current waiting period is 12-18 months

Next steps:

  • Fill out application and take it to 317 Caldwell Street Extension Chapel Hill, NC 27516 (8:30-5:00 Monday-Friday).
  • Application and other forms found under "Forms" at: https://www.townofchapelhill.org/town-hall/departments-services/housing-and-community/public-housing
records.Eligibility_Criteria__c:
For families who(se)…

  • Total annual household income is within the limits established by HUD for the area (see very bottom)
    • 2018 HUD income limits (https://www.hudexchange.info/resource/reportmanagement/published/HOME_IncomeLmts_State_NC_2018.pdf)
  • Net family assets & income are insufficient to obtain adequate accommodations on the private market
  • Have no record (in past 5 years) of neighborhood disturbances, destruction of property, or negative habits that affect the health, safety or welfare of other tenants.
  • Have no record (in past 10 years) of violent criminal activity or (in past 15 years) illegal drug activity
  • Preference for applicants who:
    • ​Are working, disabled, or elderly
    • Pay 50% of their income for rent/utilities
    • Are involuntarily displaced
  • Community service requirement for all residents over 18.

records.Description_Short__c: Local public transportation services for Durham.

records.Name: Alliance Behavioral Healthcare
records.Description_Short__c: 24 hour phone line is answered by behavioral health professionals who provide telephone screenings, help with enrollment of individuals for mental health, intellectual/developmental disabilities and substance abuse services, share information on available community resources, provide crisis intervention by telephone or arrange for an emergency face-to-face clinical assessment, or a referral for services to Alliance’s local network of providers.
records.F_Description_Short__c: Alliance Behavioral Healthcare is a Managed Care Organization (MCO) that manages the public mental health, intellectual/ developmental disability and substance abuse services for the citizens of Durham, Wake, Cumberland and Johnston counties. They work to
records.Detailed_Description__c:
Manages mental health services in Durham to connect patients with providers. Enhanced benefits available for some individuals on Medicaid or uninsured. In some cases, current clients can receive funding for housing or rental assistance Monday-Friday, 8:30am5:00pm

Prefer that you Call the 24 hour toll-free Alliance Access and Information Line at (800) 510-9132
records.Eligibility_Criteria__c:
• Chronic mental illness, developmental disability, or substance abuse
  • Uninsured or has Medicaid
